awd_abstract_narration:
The project concerns the anomalous spectral and diffusive properties of quasiperiodic and other deterministic and random structures. This is research on the fundamental properties of disordered systems that serve as models of systems with impurities.  Quasiperiodic operators provide central or important models for integer quantum Hall effect, experimental quasicrystals and the quantum chaos theory.  The development of the rigorous theory is expected to contribute to the understanding of all the above phenomena, and in particular, may lead to finding new materials with desired physical properties.  Disordered systems are also used in modeling many other micro and macro effects: from quantum localization to earthquakes. The proposed topics include studying properties of both highly and weakly disordered systems of Quantum Mechanics that demonstrate certain anomalous behavior.  An integral part of the project concerns educating graduate students and other young researchers. 

The project consists of several parts.  One is to prove the extended states for multidimensional quasiperiodic operators. Another is to study the effects of interaction in tight-binding quasi-periodic models. One more is to develop a new, determinantal, approach to multidimensional Anderson localization.   Other important objectives are the study of issues related to certain models of quantum chaos. The project involves the continuing development of non-perturbative methods for the proofs of localization type effects both in Schrodinger operators and in quantum spin systems, percolation and contact processes in disordered environments, as well as for the study of absolutely continuous spectrum.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of this project consists in solving several open
problems in analysis motivated by questions in solid state physics and in
development of corresponding theories. Our work has been mostly related to sharp transitions and critical phenomena in spectral theory. The results on quasiperiodic operators included solution oif the critical singular continuous spectrum conjecture from 1982 for all frequencies, the discovery of the universal structure of eigenfunctions throughout the pure point region, with arithmetical hierarchy in the regime of phase resonances,  sharp arithmetic transitions between point and singular continuous spectrum and proof of the arithmetic spectral transition conjectures for phase and resonances, sharp arithmetic criterion for full dimensionality of the spectral measure for general analytic operators, the development of tools to prove spectral continuity, leading to natural examples with dierent Hausdorff and packing dimension and other unusual phenomena. The results on multidimensional quasiperiodic operators include proof of Anderson localization for any dimension of the underlying torus and large coupling Anderson localization for the most general class of quasiperiodic operators appearing as Aubry duals of operators with analytic potentials. A  criterion for dual exponential dynamical localization, leading to the first such result in the multi-dimensional case was developed, and an arithmetic version of Anderson localization was established via reducibility, the result only previously available by the localization method in our earlier work Additionally, spectral theory of analytic Schrodinger operators over circle diffeomorphisms was developed, and a sharp criterion for absence of point spectrum was proved. The first asymptotically hyperbolic  non-compact Riemannian manifolds with dense singular continuous spectrum embedded in the ac spectrum of the Laplace-Beltrami operators were constructed, with sharp asymptotic curvature control for the possibility of such embedding.

 Our focus has been both on developing new methods and theories in this branch of analysis/dynamical systems and on applications to models that are of interest to the physics community. As such, we obtained new results and proved open conjectures on the quantum graph model of graphene in a magnetic eld, almost Mathieu, Maryland, and extended Harper's operators. The project contributed to the training of two postdoctoral fellows,  fiour graduate students, and two visiting graduate students.
